Expectation1: Teaching children moral values and discipline
Situation1: The child is running around in a supermarket, and the parent needs to correct the behavior
Situation2: A main production unit has paused for thirty minutes because of recurring sensor errors.
Story: I was pushing the shopping cart through the supermarket, my mind half on the grocery list and half on the urgent call I’d just received from the plant. My phone buzzed again—another message from my supervisor: “Production line down. Sensor error. Need you ASAP.” I could picture the blinking red lights, the mounting pressure as every minute ticked by. But right now, my son darted away from me, weaving between displays, giggling as he knocked a box of cereal to the floor. Other shoppers stared. I felt their judgment, the silent expectation that I’d step in, teach him respect and self-control. I wanted to kneel down, look him in the eye, and explain why we don’t run indoors, why we respect shared spaces. But my mind raced with technical diagrams and error codes, the weight of the halted production line pressing on my shoulders. I gripped the cart, torn between the parent I needed to be and the technician everyone was waiting for, my heart pounding as I stood frozen in the aisle, caught between two worlds demanding all of me at once.
